Dear all, in recent days, Hong Kong has spiralled into a chaotic state due to the Hong Kong government’s reluctance to address the five appeals decreed among the majority of the protesters.

Such aloofness from the government and the forceful violence initiated by the Hong Kong police force altogether pushed the protesters over the edge and the majority of the Hong Kong citizens to decide to step up against the institution.

During August 4th to 5th, different assemblies were conducted by the citizens from Causeway Bay, the Cross-Harbour Tunnel to various districts in Kowloon. At the assembled locations, the police force decided to use unnecessary violence against the citizens, including massive showering of expired tear gas bombs and unreasonable arrest of peaceful citizens.

In view of such violence, we are disheartened to learn that the Chief Executive, Carrie Lam-Cheng-Yuet-Ngor, fails to crawl out of her bunker and address the appeals in a direct and explicit way. Instead, she exploits verbal tactics in the hope of bringing division among the citizens and dismantling the voice of the mass.

This is an act that shows the Chief Executive to be an inadequate one, as she fails to respond to the five appeals of the majority, of which would be long mentioned and reiterated by the public throughout these days of disharmony and conflict.

To avoid further misunderstandings, we wish to restate the main five appeals again, including: 1) The government should withdraw the extradition bill in a legal and lawful manner, 2) The government should abrogate her definition of ‘riot’ in view of protests in recent days, 3) The government should revoke her accusations and arrests against all protesters in recent days, 4) The government should immediately set up an independent investigation counsel on the abuse of power by the Hong Kong police force, 5) The government should immediately declare the implementation of universal suffrage in view of Hong Kong Chief Executive and the members of legislative counsel.

Thank you and please remember that we stand as one, and we stand for Hong Kong.
